subject: Re: [junit] Chris' excellent test-splitting adventure
msgSnippet: Sometimes it is necessary to use the sourceforge staff to do a rename of directories instead of a refactoring. We had lots of problems when we moved our
messageBody:
Sometimes it is necessary to use the sourceforge staff to do a rename of
directories instead of a refactoring.

We had lots of problems when we moved our package structure from
com.xxx.yyy to wicket.zzz because CVS was still checking the whole
com.xxx.yyy source tree. When we had sf.net staff remove the com.xxx.yyy
directory structure in CVS we saw our synchronization times drop a few
minutes.

Refactor your package structure often enough and you are really screwed
when synchronizing with sf.net.

Martijn

Chris Dollin wrote:

> On Tuesday 07 June 2005 19:59, Jeff Nielsen wrote:
> > We do use CVS for all of our projects here and don't suffer from the
> kinds
> > of issues Chris talks about either. I can't imagine a simple checkin or
> > update taking long enough that you would have time to read mail or
> news.
> > We also rename checked-in classes almost daily, and the only CVS issue
> > there is "losing" easy access to the file's history.
> >
> > Surely the CVS slowness (is the server remote?) is one of the real
> issues
> > to be addressed in Chris's situation. Interesting how a "technical"
> issue
> > like that can drive the kinds of refactorings people are willing/able to
> > do.
>
> The CVS server is remote; specifically, it's SourceForge.
>
> It occurs to me to wonder if it's really the server, or if there's some
> network issue between here and there. (The experience is the same, but
> some things are, in principle, easier to fix ...)
>
> --
> Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
> It's called *extreme* programming, not *stupid* programming.
>
>
